Key Match Events: The Washington Wizards traveled to Orlando and got blown out by a middling Magic squad missing its best player (Paolo Banchero) and starting center (Wendell Carter Jr.).
The Wizards kept things respectable into the third quarter, at which point the Magic pulled away.
Washington fell behind by as much as 33 in the fourth quarter and lost by 27.
Bilal Coulibaly bounced back from a couple subpar games with a hyper-efficient 20 points, 6 rebounds, 6 assists.
Rookie forward Kyshawn George had a terrific first half, finishing with 15 points on 9 shots, hit 4-8 from three, and had 7 rebounds.
Alex Sarr had a couple nice defensive moments, which included a steal and two blocks.
Jordan Poole had another haphazard game with iffy decision-making and nonexistent defense.
Corey Kispert had yet another awful shooting night — 1-7 from the floor and 0-3 from deep.
Post-Match Reflections: Head coach Brian Keefe has gone with a tight rotation so far this season, using basically seven guys for real minutes.
The good thing about the rotation: the kids are getting lots of playing time.
A team playing this many youngsters and middling veterans is going to take its lumps in a lot of games, and last night’s matchup with the Magic is an example of it.
The payoff for suffering through it may come in a few years. For now, enjoy those flashes and hope they turn into steady production.
